review_preview: Came to Madrid with my girlfriend to meet my mum ! We all love Italian food and it's hard to find Italian restaurants in Madrid ! We found this restaurant in a side street with a great Spanish atmosphere. We managed to get a table...
review_full: Came to Madrid with my girlfriend to meet my mum ! We all love Italian food and it's hard to find Italian restaurants in Madrid ! We found this restaurant in a side street with a great Spanish atmosphere. We managed to get a table for 3 but it was inside so we thought we will go to a bar next door and wait for a table to be free outside. After a short period of time we got a table. The waiter Luigi was brilliant. He was enthusiastic, welcoming and always had a smile on his face. All three of us thought this is what we've been looking for. All the staff in Malatesta were great but Luigi was looking after us and we couldn't of asked for a better waiter. Grazie Luigi for a great last night in Madrid. Back to Glasgow and back to work tomorrow :(

review_preview: We were craving a break from tapas so we decided to try our luck at this Italian restaurant. I'm so glad we did. Plaza Mayor has a lot of touristy restaurants with horrible food but the food here was freshly prepared and very good. The...
review_full: We were craving a break from tapas so we decided to try our luck at this Italian restaurant. I'm so glad we did. Plaza Mayor has a lot of touristy restaurants with horrible food but the food here was freshly prepared and very good. The waiters provided excellent service. We sat in the main dining room just inside the doors. It was slightly warmer there because of the kitchen but they had ceiling fans which made it more comfortable. You can also sit outside or in the basement dining room, which is surprisingly nice. We started with the arugula and caprese salads. We also tried the mushroom and fresh clams pastas. The cheapest bottle of Rioja was really good. They brought us a limoncello for a nightcap. Very good. Highly recommend.

review_preview: we began our Calle Cava Baja tapas crawl here at La Concha.  We ordered up a ca√±a and a glass of sangria at the bar.  The place is very small with only about 6 seats at the bar upstairs.  We struck up a conversation with...
review_full: we began our Calle Cava Baja tapas crawl here at La Concha. We ordered up a ca√±a and a glass of sangria at the bar. The place is very small with only about 6 seats at the bar upstairs. We struck up a conversation with 2 interesting gentlemen from the Netherlands sitting next to us. They said they were wine aficionados and were checking out the neighborhood bars. They also said there was more seating downstairs, but we chose to stand at the bar, which turned out to be a good choice, because a couple seated next to us left after about 10 minutes.  With our new friends recommending the seafood at La Concha, I had the tosta de bacalao ahumado (smoked cod on toast) and it was amazingly good! My gf had tosta de gambas (Prawns on toast (with mayonnaise and spring onion spread). She said it was so good she could have eaten more!  Anyway, the food was very good, the drinks were good, the service was excellent and the ambiance and companionship at the bar was good. I would definitely recommend Taberna La Concha without any reservations!

review_preview: 6 of us ate here on our recent trip to Madrid. We came out at night looking to pop into a couple tapas bars and decided to start at Casa Lucas. We arrived just as it was opening at 8pm and we're lucky enough to...
review_full: 6 of us ate here on our recent trip to Madrid. We came out at night looking to pop into a couple tapas bars and decided to start at Casa Lucas. We arrived just as it was opening at 8pm and we're lucky enough to get a table as less than 10 mins later the place was full and people were being turned away or told to wait for a table. Without doubt Casa Lucas sell top quality tapas and wine and it would have been very easy to have a full meal here ( maybe next time). Everything we ordered was first class with both hot and cold pinchos being worthy of mention. In addition the service was first class. They do take bookings and making a booking would be worthwhile if you want to avoid disappointment. Highly recommended for either a stop on a tapas tour or a more substantial meal.

I stopped in about 9.45 pm and asked for a little two top table for myself and they made me feel so welcome. I had a lovely glass of wine and the Mediterranean salad and grilled shrimp in garlic and it was the perfect amount of food for a non-Spaniard at that time of night. Both were very very good and when I was checking out they offered me a free post dinner taste of a lovely aperitif. They spoke English well enough that I was in good hands and very happy I had chosen this restaurant. The outside doesn't look like much and it was very narrow and somewhat small inside but it was lovely with a very clean restroom. I would definitely recommend. Enjoy!

Our waiter was great, spoke good English and was patient with out limited spanish. Reccomened a brilliant wine. Between the 3 of us 2 had Pizzas and one the steak salad. We all were in agreement that this was one of the best meals we had ever had in an Italian restaurant. The Pizzas are obviously fresh in a wood fired oven and have a great taste. They have a variety of topping along with other options on their Menu. They also have a specials board and gave us a great apetiser whilst we waited for a meals. The price was extremely reasonable - ever more so considering this is just a stones throw from Plaza Mayor.  Tip - We walked past at about 7:30 and the place actually looked shut down ! Don't be fooled. I think they open around 8 - 8:30.

My husband ordered Tagliolini scoglio, con almejas, mejillones, gambas y tomate (seafood pasta with clams, mussels, praws and tomato sauce) while I opted for the Tagliolini pesto, gamberi e cherry (pesto pasta with jumbo shrimp and cherry tomatoes). I liked my dish better than my husband's, but both were good. The pasta was flavorful and cooked to perfection (al-dente). We also split the almond chocolate cake with ice cream, which was very good. I would have happily gone back another night for dinner, but we decided to opt for the dinner with the flamenco show we booked.

review_full: We were hoping for some basic Italian fare and we got that. We arrived just after 9pm and there were a few customers sitting outside but we opted to sit inside. It was warm and cozy and had a good old school vibe. They start you off with a package of bread sticks and some nice plain pizza bread. I ordered the Linguine with Clams which was fine but nothing special and my husband ordered the Spaghetti with Octopus in Marinara - the better of the two dishes. His Marinara was just a little spicy and the Octopus was plentiful and a tiny bit overcooked, but it still had good flavor. The service was fine at first with us being initially seated by the main waiter. But as the dinner went on, we were "tended" to by the bartender who took care of the indoor section. He was inattentive and when we finally asked for the check, he ignored us and continued to clean his glasses. He went on to attend other people and we had to ask again after about 15-20 minutes of being what felt like purposefully ignored. Too many other restaurants nearby to recommend this one.

review_full: I guess am not the only one that has come to this Madrid restaurant, thinking it‚Äôs the sister one of New York‚Äôs restaurant. It was really good it was not! This is indeed a very charming trattoria with very authentic cooking. We asked the waiter and the owner explained us they are totally independent. Most of the crew seem Italian and they claim they prepare all pasta fresh every day (it must be true, delicious indeed). We tried the ‚Äúmenu to share‚Äù, so that you share one starter (big ones), then a main for each of us and the you share a desert (a very nice formula for couples, just 19 EURO each). Everything was delicious carpaccio&rucula, risotto funghi, shrimp ravioli and torta caprese. Add to this beautiful patio-dinner a wonderful walk around the most famous old Madrid landmarks and you get the perfect evening. What a shame not to have such a place back home ‚Ä¶

We were served a little sardine with a bit of sauce on a rice crackers to start, tasty, we both ordered different sherrys cause we could and the ordered a lentil dish with ham and foi Gras, super tasty, served with gluten free baguette which was very good, I am not gluten free but the texture of this bread was comparable to a regular wheat baguette. We then ordered a pork cheek dish, it came with a beautiful sauce, mashed potatoes and small green beans, again really tasty then we had a baked red pepper in cheesy goodness, more bread. We were ready to leave but we're coerced by one of the servers to have desert, gluten free "torrija", Slice of bread soaked in milk to which is added cinnamon and lemon rind, which is passed through beaten egg and fried in abundant oil; Served with sprinkled with sugar or washed with honey; You can also soak in wine instead of in milk. This was a real treat for my wife and me too. Then they sent us on our way with a half strawberry drizzled with chocolate, 33.50 Euros seems like standard prices. I think their board outside also said vegan as well. Sometimes it's hard to find any gluten free options when we travel, this was an awesome and easy experience. Thanks La Concha!

review_preview: Casa Lucas is a tiny restaurant. Try to get in early or be prepared to wait in line! Hubby and I ordered some hot tapas and two dishes to share amongst ourselves. For tapas, we had the grilled pork served on white bread and a...
review_full: Casa Lucas is a tiny restaurant. Try to get in early or be prepared to wait in line! Hubby and I ordered some hot tapas and two dishes to share amongst ourselves. For tapas, we had the grilled pork served on white bread and a bed a caramalized onions. The pork was so succulent and went very well with the sweet onions. I am not a fan of onions but had to admit that the combo really worked. For our mains, we ordered the bacon wrapped calamari with ink mousse that everyone raves about and ink cannelloni with seafood served with cream sauce. The calamari was to die for! Thick strips of lightly battered calamari wrapped with bacon, then tossed in the ink mousse. The presentation was really nice when the dish was brought to our table but then the waiter quickly cut and mix everything up before I could snap a photo of it. It looked like a big pile of mess when he was done but it was very tasty. They adjusted the serving size from three bundles of calamari to two because there were only the two of us. We both wish they had not done that! We could have eaten the full portion... I personally did not enjoy the cannelloni at all. It had only a few tiny pieces of shrimps inside and the rest was roastsd vegetables. I found the cream sauce not complimenting the ink pasta too well but hubby happily gobbled everything up. Overall, dinner was very good. The calamari is a must for those who go to Casa Lucas. It was a truly delicious and memorable dish.

Prices are on the low side compared with Germany but also with Madrid.

review_preview: I looked up Trip Advisor for a nice Italian to eat in for lunch on the 3rd day of our stay in Madrid, as my husband is half-Italian, an excellent Italian cook and was missing his pasta! We were impressed with the reviews for Malatesta...
review_full: I looked up Trip Advisor for a nice Italian to eat in for lunch on the 3rd day of our stay in Madrid, as my husband is half-Italian, an excellent Italian cook and was missing his pasta! We were impressed with the reviews for Malatesta and decided to pay it a visit. Reviews say the lunch deal was great value - to be honest it was average, as we'd been finding lots of great deals just by chance and this one was actually slightly more expensive than others (probably due to the central location). The restaurant is down a lane, is appealing and inviting, but once sat, the staff really couldn't be bothered with us to be honest. We don't speak much Spanish but tried our best to decipher the menu with our phrasebook, so I only had 2 questions about the dishes, but the waitress just sighed and gave half-hearted replies. We asked for 'pan', (bread), the waiter said 'si' but 15 minutes later no bread has been brought. We then asked the waitress the same question and she dumped 3 packets of mass-produced breadsticks on our table, saying 'this is all we have' (how can a genuine Italian restaurant not have any bread?!). Starters arrived promptly and were tasty and fresh, so no complaints there. I ordered the pizza for my main course and my husband the ravioli. Like previous reviewers have said, the pizza was massive, but it was also authentic and delicious. My husband counted that he had been given 8 pieces of ravioli (fair enough - it was lunchtime after all, but next to my huge pizza the portion looked a bit stingy). But what made this so annoying was that the table next to us appeared to be locals, and when their ravioli arrived, it was a much larger portion, complete with parmesan and basil garnishes. We were not offered parmesan or black pepper and had to continuously ask for things when they should have been offered automatically. We passed on dessert, even though it was included, not because of the food but because of the service. Its a shame - I hate it when places assume that just because you are a visitor then its ok to give bad service. Surely they must know sites like Trip Advisor are invaluable to their business. Hope the service improves as the food was actually really good.

review_preview: The offer of italian food in Madrid is large and diverse, ranging from walk-by pizza to sophisticated signature restaurants. Malatesta successfully strikes a difficult balance of value, service and atmosphere. The place offers a terraza, a first floor with windows and an intimate basement, perfect...
review_full: The offer of italian food in Madrid is large and diverse, ranging from walk-by pizza to sophisticated signature restaurants. Malatesta successfully strikes a difficult balance of value, service and atmosphere. The place offers a terraza, a first floor with windows and an intimate basement, perfect for a meal in the blazing Castillan summer. I been there twice, most recently with my girlfriend, with whom we are always on the hunt for good "menu del dia" lunches in Madrid. We sat in the basement, and ordered from the prix fixe menu (12‚Ç¨). Our firsts were a tuna carpaccio and italian croquetas, both very good. The tuna was chilled and sliced thin with a drizzle of olive oil, very well done. The italian croquetas were stuffed with Cabrales cheese, and had a silky texture and satisfying substance. A good start indeed. Seconds were a zucchini and pesto lasagna and penne bolognese. The lasagna was light and flavorful and the penne were great, with a slow-cooked, rich bolognese sauce with the right acidity and balance. Desserts: panna cotta with a rasperry coulis and sliced pineapple with vainilla ice cream. Very good! Bottom line: an excellent value for lunch, will love to try it for dinner, choosing from the full menu. Go alone, go with friends, but go. Mangia, che ti fa' benne!

review_full: This was our first meal in Spain during our 9 day family trip and it made a lasting impression. I contacted the restaurant via email to make a reservation for lunch at 13:30 on a week day and they responded to confirm. When we got there it was still not open even though it's already 13:30. We almost left in disappointment but decided to wait around a little longer to try our luck. Sure enough eventually two guys showed up to open the door and the place was packed full right away. Since it was our first meal, we had no idea where to start and just randomly ordered some dishes. The staff was friendly and communicated well in English. We especially enjoyed the calamari with ink sauce and the ox tail. Like others have said the menu isn't very big but everything was delicious. Price was fair as well for the quality of food.

Things have changed in two years.

title_review: Very good food and a great place for al fresco dining
review_preview: We went here twice during our five night stay in Madrid. On both occasions, my partner had the pizza which was excellent. We shared the Puzzanella and I had the pasta al norman on the first night and the linguine gamberoni. All in all, it...
review_full: We went here twice during our five night stay in Madrid. On both occasions, my partner had the pizza which was excellent. We shared the Puzzanella and I had the pasta al norman on the first night and the linguine gamberoni. All in all, it was very, very good.  The alleyway it is on doesn't have any good views, but there is a lot of life down the street and if you can get a table outside, then it is a nice place to sample some Madrid nightlife. Even if you can't get a table outside, the food is worth going inside for.

review_preview: My wife is Japanese...lived in Japan for years...so we know how hard it is to find authentic Japanese good abroad. Specifically, Kansai (Osaka) has a unique selection of foods that are hard to find anywhere. We were so excited to see many selections that you...
review_full: My wife is Japanese...lived in Japan for years...so we know how hard it is to find authentic Japanese good abroad. Specifically, Kansai (Osaka) has a unique selection of foods that are hard to find anywhere. We were so excited to see many selections that you never find sushi restaurants...specifically the Okonomiyaki! It's fantastic here!!! Just like Osaka (and even other area's of Japan's style too). We came back multiple times during our stay...as this place is just a gem. The staff are really cool too and are mostly young guys and girls from Japan. It's really cool to be able to see them cooking while you eat because of their open kitchen.  We recommend this place if you are looking for real Japanese food (an not just another sushi restaurant). We will definitely come back!

title_review: What an amazing Japanese culinary experience !!
review_preview: For context, I travel through European & Africa a Lot, and get the chance to eat at some great restaurants during work!!On a personal holiday I came across Sublime Tokyo, sounded great but with all of the starry eyed "on holiday" reviewers I think...
review_full: For context, I travel through European & Africa a Lot, and get the chance to eat at some great restaurants during work!! On a personal holiday I came across Sublime Tokyo, sounded great but with all of the starry eyed "on holiday" reviewers I think the average hotdog stand would get 4.5, however this is outstanding enough to need to call it out. Genuine Japanese with a real fusion kitchen with a lot of tradition not a cook book, a hope and a prayer. Chicken teriyaki lovely, teppan-gyozu amazing and the "round" salmon and tuna nigiri had perfectly su'd rice, an absolute delight .. Definitely try it!! I will return before i return home

review_preview: We stopped here based on TripAdvisor reviews and were not disappointed.  This fine restaurant is located off on a quite side street near the well-known Chocolateria San Gines.  There is a small dining room on the main floor and a larger dining area downstairs.  They...
review_full: We stopped here based on TripAdvisor reviews and were not disappointed. This fine restaurant is located off on a quite side street near the well-known Chocolateria San Gines. There is a small dining room on the main floor and a larger dining area downstairs. They open at 1:30 pm. We arrived on a Saturday at 2:00 and didn¬¥t have any problem being seated right away. But it got busy quickly, so if you plan on eating later, best to have a reservation. They offer a daily special for about 19 Euro pp, which includes one appetizer to share, to main courses and a dessert to share. We opted to share a Provolone cheese appetizer that was very good. It comes with provolone baked over tomatoes and a pizza like bread. I then had the stuffed tortellini with bolognese and my wife had a chicken and vegetable pasta dish. We were very happy with the food and the service, and will definitely be back. The table next to us ordered a couple of pizzas and they looked very, very good. Our bill came to about 32 Euros. Bathrooms are in the basement and were very clean. All in all, I highly recommend this restaurant if you¬¥re looking for great Italian in Madrid.

review_preview: Girlfriend and I had two pincho items - one of each cold and hot, the Rice (risotto with foie and quail egg), the Octopus carpaccio and a bottle of wine. The Jumilla (half spinach and half leek pate with prawns on top) pincho and soy...
review_full: Girlfriend and I had two pincho items - one of each cold and hot, the Rice (risotto with foie and quail egg), the Octopus carpaccio and a bottle of wine. The Jumilla (half spinach and half leek pate with prawns on top) pincho and soy chicken pincho were both fantastic! The Octopus carpaccio was great as well, but the Risotto was only ok as the richness of the risotto, the foie, and the egg created for a boring taste/texture. Would highly recommend and we will return to try other items on their menu!  A bit on the pricey side - ?20 for each of the entrees and ?6 for each of the pinchos (each order came with two slices of amazingly crusty fresh bread with amazing toppings). We waited for about 10 minutes for a table for two when we arrived at 1030pm. Total was ?70 for two people, inclusive of the bottle of wine. title_review: Genuine Japanese food at an affordable price

Sorry but I hate when a restaurant dumps multiple plates on a table. complete lack of coordination between front and back of house as for the food ... the pork with kimchi sauce was tasty. the salmon sashimi was enormous slices (more slabs as they were pretty thick) ... a good portion at a modest price so ... go with a group ... dont be picky about things as I am ... but if you are, you might want to look elsewhere

title_review: Excellent Italian food, service and value.
review_preview: Based on its strong Trip Advisor rating, my wife and I visited Malatesta on the first night of our recent stay in Madrid. The experience was so enjoyable that we returned on our second night, too.We did not reserve either evening, which meant that...
review_full: Based on its strong Trip Advisor rating, my wife and I visited Malatesta on the first night of our recent stay in Madrid. The experience was so enjoyable that we returned on our second night, too. We did not reserve either evening, which meant that we could not get an outside table, but it was fine eating inside on the ground floor the first evening and, possibly even better, in the basement on the second night. The menu contains a good range of Italian staple items. We had pasta dishes on both visits and they were freshly cooked and very tasty. And reasonably priced. The bread basket (complimentary for the first night but charged at a very modest 1 euro each on the second - I suspect now that they may have simply forgotten to charge us on the first visit) is brilliant.  The service was first class and very friendly (thank you to waiter John on night one) with English spoken.

title_review: Great trattoria in the center of Madrid!
review_preview: We ran into this restaurant (located in a lane off Plaza Mayor) as we walked around the center of Madrid and since we all like Italian food, we decided to try it out for dinner that evening; we were a party of 6 and were...
review_full: We ran into this restaurant (located in a lane off Plaza Mayor) as we walked around the center of Madrid and since we all like Italian food, we decided to try it out for dinner that evening; we were a party of 6 and were able to reserve one of the few outside tables in front of the establishment.  This is a trattoria specializing in a limited number of appetizers (the oven cooked provolone cheese with San Marzano tomato sauce as well as the mussels in a spicy tomato sauce were so amazing that a colleague and I ordered them again when we returned a few days later as a party of 8). There is variety in the pasta choices and the pasta is cooked to perfection (al dente); I particularly enjoyed the spaghetti with spicy octopus. Pizzas with quality ingredients and constituting a meal unto itself are cooked in a wood burning oven.  We also found a nice reasonable priced Primitivo red to accompany our meal. Prices overall are fairly reasonable considering you are in the center of Madrid.  The restaurant has a ground level section and a section in the basement which I do not recommend if you are a bit claustrophobic.

title_review: Excellent service, quaint atmosphere, delicious food!
review_preview: We went here on our final night and had a table booked for 6 people for 9:30pm. When we realised we were running late I called them and asked could we move our booking to 10pm which was no problem at all to them, as...
review_full: We went here on our final night and had a table booked for 6 people for 9:30pm. When we realised we were running late I called them and asked could we move our booking to 10pm which was no problem at all to them, as long as we had finished by 11:30pm because that's when they close (fair enough, it was us that were running late). The restaurant is situated on a little side street just off Calle Mayor, with some tables outside and some inside. They made us feel extremely welcome, spoke good English (very rare in Madrid) and explained any questions that we had about the menu thoroughly. With it only being a small restaurant, the atmosphere was very intimate and quaint. The food was also delicious, from the pizzas to the tagliatelle, it was all very good. We had no complaints out of the 6 of us. When we had finished our meal they then served us coffees and limoncello drinks on the house. If I went back to Madrid I would definitely go back there. If you're looking for flash and brash type of restaurant then don't go, but if you're after authentic Italian cuisine and service in a quaint atmosphere then this is the place for you. Thanks Elia and you're team.

The server was so friendly and helpful when we were trying to choose and also when I was curious about what others had ordered. It is disconcerting to watch her run up and down the stairs with every order and dish- I wonder why there isn't a dumbwaiter, but that would eliminate her daily workout program. Call ahead for seating- it's very small.

title_review: Excellent service and gluten free tapas
review_preview: Discovered this little taberna after researching gluten free restaurants in Madrid.  First night and we arrived at the taberna at 7.50, not realising that, in Madrid, restaurants don't usually start serving dinner until after 8pm and that they really fill up around 11pm!However, we...
review_full: Discovered this little taberna after researching gluten free restaurants in Madrid. First night and we arrived at the taberna at 7.50, not realising that, in Madrid, restaurants don't usually start serving dinner until after 8pm and that they really fill up around 11pm! However, we were starving after a long day of travel and couldn't wait that long. Luckily, we were seated quickly and reassured that all but three of the tapas available were gluten-free. Gluten-free bread was quickly produced and beer was also available. My coeliac husband had the spicy beef curry and declared it amazing. It looked like slow cooked brisket to me. I had the tomato and mozzarella tower and meatballs and loved them both. The staff were lovely - the man who seated us didn't have much English (but had more English than I had Spanish!) and fetched a lovely lady to help out. Both were friendly and charming and added to a wonderful experience. Its not the most glamorous of places - just a few tables in the basement to add to a few seats round the upstairs bar, but it was a good night out.

Their specialty is a vermouth cocktail and of course it being August we had tinto verano which tasted much much better than the usual red wine mixed with lemon soda which we found to be too sweet. The bartender upstairs was a true mixologist and the drinks were lovely. The food was very good as well. We had an assortment of tapas and my favorite was the bresaola with parmesan tosta and the salmon with dill although we had a number of dishes and there wasn't one that I didn't care for. We loved this place so much we would return there at the end of the night before taking the Metro back to our hotel for one last glass of wine and tinto. Prices were inexpensive as well, definitely highly recommend.

review_preview: We ate here our last night in Madrid.  I wish we had found it sooner!  The meal was delicious, and Alex, or waiter, was extremely friendly and was very helpful in making wonderful suggestions. We sat outside, and had a leisurely dinner watching the street...

The meal was delicious, and Alex, or waiter, was extremely friendly and was very helpful in making wonderful suggestions. We sat outside, and had a leisurely dinner watching the street life. The wine was perfect. I strongly suggest the goat cheese salad, and the wood fired pizzas were divine. Enjoy!

We made reservations online and they did not seem to have them on their clipboard, but when I showed them the email confirmation, they honored the reservation and sat us in the quiet, charming, cozy basement. The red house wine was not very good, so we ordered a bottle of rioja--which was lovely. We ordered the dinner for two option, but it was so much food that we could not finish the dessert. All in all, a good choice.

Inattentive staff apart from bar waitress who could see our predicament and brought bill when it had been asked for 10 minutes previously and gave us a complimentary Limoncello which was the nicest part of the otherwise poor experience. Don't bother. Style over substance unfortunately- others were also leaving before dessert. Think they're complacent because of location.

title_review: Far and away the best we found in Madrid!
review_preview: The first night we ate here, the place filled at about 9pm with primarily locals - one of the sure signs we use for spotting a winner.  This small and simply appointed restaurant has a great staff - knowledgeable, friendly and attentive, but the reason...
review_full: The first night we ate here, the place filled at about 9pm with primarily locals - one of the sure signs we use for spotting a winner.  This small and simply appointed restaurant has a great staff - knowledgeable, friendly and attentive, but the reason to go there is the food. We found on later trips that this is certainly a top choice in Madrid for tapas, but that first evening we learned that this is THE place to go for really fine dining. Simple, authentic and delicious! Their food, while not necessarily historically authentic are certainly both creative and consistent with the spirit of the traditional foods of Spain. Their wine list is sufficient to satisfy. They have made two interesting choices of which the visitor should be aware. First, beverage choices are limited to wine, water, juices, coffee or tea. The serve no soft drinks. Second, they offer no desserts. Sans desserts, our meals at Casa Lucus were truly memorable.

title_review: Been here countless times... Never disappoints
review_preview: Casa Lucas is consistently great. Tonight, we tried the couscous, something that doesn't normally appeal to me. It was outstanding -- topped with a white-meat chicken curry that must have been cooked in a tagine. Highly spiced and savory with tomatoes. It was beautiful. Then,...
review_full: Casa Lucas is consistently great. Tonight, we tried the couscous, something that doesn't normally appeal to me. It was outstanding -- topped with a white-meat chicken curry that must have been cooked in a tagine. Highly spiced and savory with tomatoes. It was beautiful. Then, I must also recommend the pinchos, which are large here. Get the mancha, a vegetable pisto covered with a quail egg and crispy Jam√≥n strips, and the one with the solomillo, in this case a grilled piece of pork loin atop caramelized onions. My husband also loved the Madrid pincho, an omelette of morcilla that I must admit was delicious, despite my involuntary queasiness with respect to blood sausage. As always, the tuna tataki was a delight. Yes, it's pricier than the other places on the cava Baja and throughout Madrid in general, but it's always good. Worth the extra scratch if you can manage it.

There is a good mix of Americans and Spaniards, along with menus printed in Spanish and English. They also have a great gluten free menu, with gf options clearly labeled. La Concha is located in the La Latina neighborhood, which is a favorite bar neighborhood in Madrid. The food is great, and the drinks are fantastic as well.

review_preview: Taverns la Concha is easy to miss as you walk down Cava Baja. It's just a door into a small bar area that looks to hold about 9 people at most with stairs leading down to a lower level where there are a half dozen...
review_full: Taverns la Concha is easy to miss as you walk down Cava Baja. It's just a door into a small bar area that looks to hold about 9 people at most with stairs leading down to a lower level where there are a half dozen tables. If you suffer from celiac this place has to be on your list to visit. We arrived on a Sunday night about 7:30 pm, there were a couple people at the bar and lady behind the bar promptly greeted us and spoke English much better than we spoke Spanish. She directed us to lower level and when we mentioned we were 'celiacos' she was able to provide us with a gluten free menu in English and also pointed out a few items that could be made GF on the main menu. We ordered 4 tapas, a cheese plate, a pork in three cheese sauce, meatballs, and beef in a spicy red curry. They were all served with GF bread and were very flavorful. My personal favorite was the beef in the spicy red curry sauce, while my wife preferred the pork in a 3 cheese sauce. Overall they were all delicious. One of the highlights I will admit was a good tasting Gluten Free Beer. The lady behind the bar was friendly and efficient. She really took care of us and we will definitely stop there again.

We arrived early so we were seated downstairs comfortably and were able to order approx. five plates for our group of six. We had two members of our group who were gluten free so we were pleasantly surprised to see that they had a separate menu of gluten free tapas. The wine was very reasonably priced as well. The service was attentive and very friendly as well. By the time we left, the upstairs area was very crowded showing how popular and good this place is.

review_preview: I'm not quite sure why this is not higher in the tripadvisor ranking. My wife and I found his gem after combing through various foodie websites to find his place. Decor is tiny but quaint - just enough to fit roughly 20-30 people. We were...
review_full: I'm not quite sure why this is not higher in the tripadvisor ranking. My wife and I found his gem after combing through various foodie websites to find his place.  Decor is tiny but quaint - just enough to fit roughly 20-30 people. We were probably the only tourists in the restaurant but didn't get any evil eye look from the local patrons. We got lucky and grabbed a table within minutes of arrival. Our server was also very friendly and pleasant. This place is definitely not on the tourists' map but I'd imagine people will soon catch wind of it.  A small charcuterie and bread was given to us for free upon taking our seat, a pretty usual service of tapa joints. Even though this first tapa was free, the meat was just so flavorful. Our food blogs suggested the dish to try is their calamari with squid ink mayo. It's on the pricy side but it's well worth it's taste in pennies! This has got to be our dish in Madrid! I was telling our server that this dish tasted even better than the traditional "bocadillo" (calamari) sandwich the locals eat. He promptly agreed.  I wished I had taken a better photo of the squid ink dish. It arrived with whole pieces of calamari "tied together" with bacon with the squid ink mayo sauce separately in one corner. Before I had he chance, the server proceed to cut up the calamari and combining all the ingredients at table side.

title_review: First-rate tapas, open when others are closed.
review_preview: The Taberna la Concha looks like a tiny unassuming bar from the outside, but once you get seated at one of the little tables in the basement, the tapas you get are first-rate, with generous portions. We had mostly seafood; especially recommended are the salmorejo...
review_full: The Taberna la Concha looks like a tiny unassuming bar from the outside, but once you get seated at one of the little tables in the basement, the tapas you get are first-rate, with generous portions. We had mostly seafood; especially recommended are the salmorejo (a thick Andalusian tomato-based soup), the bacalao (salted and dried cod ‚Äî it's like sushi) and the two different versions of anchovies. The servers must be in excellent shape, as they make contless trips up and down the steep basement stairs to supply the diners.  A major plus of this restaurant for American diners is that it's open in the early evening, while most others don't start serving food until 8:30.

title_review: For a change of pace and taste
review_preview: As walk-in customers, we were warmly greeted and seated (and got lucky with that, as it soon packed out).  The Argentine waiter was friendly and attentive, ensuring we didn't overdo it on the ordering and offering half portions as well.  The tuna tataki was devoured...
review_full: As walk-in customers, we were warmly greeted and seated (and got lucky with that, as it soon packed out). The Argentine waiter was friendly and attentive, ensuring we didn't overdo it on the ordering and offering half portions as well. The tuna tataki was devoured - nicely (and unusually) paired with apple sauce. The oxtail was tasty although I'd have preferred one or two pieces as a appetiser rather than four as a main (so a good half portion choice?). The octopus carpaccio was nicely presented and served with deconstructed chorizo - lots of paprika and bacon bits. A decent selection of wines by the glass but bad news for those with a sweet tooth - no desserts.  So worth a visit for sure and if you can't get it don't worry - there's about a 1,000 other restaurant choices on the same street.

review_preview: What a spectacular experience I've had visiting la Manduca. The whole meal was delightful and absolutely loved it from beginning to end.We were received by who seemed to be the owner of the restaurant. He was a lovely gentleman very chatty and welcoming. We...
review_full: What a spectacular experience I've had visiting la Manduca. The whole meal was delightful and absolutely loved it from beginning to end. We were received by who seemed to be the owner of the restaurant. He was a lovely gentleman very chatty and welcoming. We were sat at our table and asked if we needed to use the restroom which, whoever knows me, I am in need of one very often. It was neat, clean and nicely decorated.  Due to Covid we were offered to look up the menus by scanning the QR but also were offered the normal menu if we found that easier which was nice of them, but my sister and I decided to go the easy way and simply scan the menu. Everything sounded so appetising that it was very hard to choose from all the options available!  While deciding what to have they kindly brought us olives, tomato dressed with salt and a peculiar but tasty olive oil and small chistorras (typical sausages from Spain). All three of them were really nice. After deliberation, we decided to share Iberian ham croquettes and goat cheese with with glazed honey, grapes and truffle. The starters were quality. The bechamel sauce was smooth and light and very tasty, the goat cheese with truffle was simply amazing. I love the contrast of a strong sour flavour mixed with the sweet flavour of honey and grapes and the truffle gave that special touch. It was absolutely delicious.  As a main I went for the beef cheeks which I had been craving for months. I even had dreamt about them! They came accompanied by boiled potatoes and carrot and an absolutely gorgeous sauce. It was so tender that it melt in my mouth. Cooked to perfection and delicious. I also ordered a red wine house from Navarra to go with it. The combination of both was really good and I enjoyed it a lot. To finish with, I went for the chocolate coulant that came with chocolate crumbs and vanilla ice cream. I also had the pleasure of tasting the Torrija (fried bread) which was to my surprise even better than the coulant. Dressed with some custard sauce and vanilla ice cream. It was the perfect end to a perfect meal. I also tried peaches from Navarra. And let me say that they were lovely too. Not too soft, not too hard, very rich and tasty.  Throughout the meal the whole staff was so nice and attentive, very professional and friendly. I love good manners and good service. The pleases, the thank yous, the clearing from the left, serving from the right, clearing the crumbs in between courses, pouring the drinks when needed, changing the cutlery for fresh ones, the details, the warnings to let you know what's coming, the pauses, the caring for the customer and their experience. That's what I felt during my meal.  The ambience of the restaurant was nice too. If you ever go to Madrid I totally recommend them, not only for the service provided but the food was outstanding.

title_review: What a jewel of a spot in
review_preview: What a jewel of a spot in central Madrid!  We travel frequently and dine regularly at Michelin - starred restaurants, so believe us when we share this incredible evening‚Äôs warm and welcoming experience.  Upon arrival, the sweet owner greeted us and explained the menu.  Feeling...
review_full: What a jewel of a spot in central Madrid! We travel frequently and dine regularly at Michelin - starred restaurants, so believe us when we share this incredible evening‚Äôs warm and welcoming experience. Upon arrival, the sweet owner greeted us and explained the menu. Feeling a bit overwhelmed with all of the delicious options, she returned and suggested some great shared plates, drawing from the freshest/favorites of the menu options. (Highlighted at this restaurant are beautifully sourced vegetables from Azagra in northern Spain.) After we had ordered a nice bottle of viognier to share, they delivered lovely crusty bread, accompanied by perfectly seasoned tomatoes and a side of sausages. We can definitely recommend the leeks topped with micro greens, spicy grilled red peppers, artichokes and thistles ( think celery) which were all shared and enjoyed. The grilled monk fish and lamb stew  for entrees were also exceptional. The meal was so well - paced, that we even decided to share a delectable dessert of carmelized, cream -filled French toast accompanied with vanilla bean ice cream. Over chamomille tea and complimentary pirouettes, our gracious hostess treated us to a sweet dessert wine that was the perfect end to a remarkable meal.  Service from our waitress was impeccable and we thank the concierge team at the Urso Hotel for their wonderful recommendation!

review_preview: Yesterday we had walked over 14 miles and we were very tired.  We messaged the owner of the apartment we were at and asked if he had a suggestion for lunch.  He suggested here.  Once we walked in, we almost turned around and walked out....
review_full: Yesterday we had walked over 14 miles and we were very tired. We messaged the owner of the apartment we were at and asked if he had a suggestion for lunch. He suggested here. Once we walked in, we almost turned around and walked out. Everyone was in suits and dresses. We were in jeans and had a backpack. But they made us feel very welcome. I think it was the owner (if she wasn't the owner, she should have been!) came and discussed the menu with us and helped us with our choices. And then we sat back and had the best meal I think I've ever had in Spain. After we had worked on the menu, a wine from Navarre was suggested to go with it. And then it started with fresh bread with olive oil (from Navarre), some tomatoes with a sprinkle of salt and some sausages.  I started with Gazpacho made with fresh tomatoes, grapes and blackberries. Best I have had in my life! And I've had quite a few! My husband had Huevos fritos con pimientos del cristal (red peppers roasted on a grill with fried eggs). We would have never thought to put this together but it was so delicious! And then we had suckling pig with fresh veggies for our main. Just absolutely amazing. At the end they brought us a small drink also from Navarre and I really wish I could remember the name. When she was describing it to us, she said it was like a Slow Gin.  I am SO happy that we didn't walk out when we saw how people were dressed. Everyone made us feel very welcome. The food was outstanding. We will definitely be back when we are next in Madrid.

All in all a simply marvelous evening. La comida es muy rica.

review_full: When you see locals eating at the place, you know you have come to the right place! The set menu costs only 10 euros and included a refreshing salad with beef tomatoes, boccini, cherry tomatoes dressed with a light pesto sauce ( or macaroni pasta), a hake- like fish with cooked spinach and potatoes, and dessert. I had the vanilla ice cream, but there were other choices- mango ice cream, chocolate cake( my husband ordered this and it was very moist), orange chocolate cake or yogurt cake with chocolate and melon, or melons, or yogurt with honey. Anyways, the vanilla ice cream was really out-of-this-world good! It also came with espresso all for 10 euros! My husband had the steak, which had good but a bit tough. A drink was also included. The service was excellent! A must try!

review_full: My husband and I decided to give this restaurant a go having read up on in on Trip Advisor. We are fussy vegetarians so Tapas was proving to be more difficult than you'd think, not always sure what the ingredients were.  We went inside the restaurant and a very friendly young lady offered us a menu. We told her we were vegetarian and she went through the menu with us and showed us what we could have, she even added a couple more that they wouldn't add meat to for us.  The food was out of this world and freshly cooked.  The waitress was helping us with our bad Spanish ( which was nice) and we came away feeling very satisfied indeed.  I highly recommend this restaurant.

I started off with a nice Spanish bread and moved on to Iberico Mixto. This was a succulent selection of Hispanic meats and could not have been more authentic! As portion sizes are relatively small in Spain, and prices are reasonable, I then went for Tataki de Atun (Tuna tataki) which was delicious also! Tiramisu finished off what must have been one of the most pleasant surprises in the food world of recent years. The staff were friendly; although they didn't speak much English, my Spanish is more than adequate to converse. ¬°Que aproveches delicioso! Highly recommended!

review_full: We made this our second stop on our tapas crawl on Calle Cava Baja in La Latina. When we told her we just wanted a few tapas and drinks, she cetrainly made up for it in the "bill". We were told that it was 25 euros but she did not give us a written bill with a list of the items as did the bar we had just previously visited. We had but two small dishes, two mosto drinks (eseentially non-alcoholic grape juice) and 2 canas of beer. By my estimation (and via thier posted menu prices) shouldn't have added up to 25 euros. Had we been locals I definitely do not think this would have happened and that is unfortunate.

review_preview: Best Tapas in Spain.  OK, Ive not eaten at all the restaurants in Spain, but this place was outstanding.  We paid allot more for meals in a number of places that did not serve food as good, or as well, as this place.We had...
review_full: Best Tapas in Spain.  OK, Ive not eaten at all the restaurants in Spain, but this place was outstanding. We paid allot more for meals in a number of places that did not serve food as good, or as well, as this place. We had the Squid, Black canneloni, Cod Fish and a couple of other dishes. These three dishes were all exceptional with a little bit of table theater to set them off. The traditional Canapes (and other tapas served on bread) were good, but these three dishes stood out. They were all recommended by a very attentive (and English speaking) waitress.  Also, great wine. Glasses were all washed with wine before our wine was poured.  It is a small place, that was really busy, but the food came out quickly and they turned the tables over quickly and they kept attention to detail in all aspects. Highly recommend.

A wonderful experience on a tapas filled night!

Overall, it's very different from the tapas you'll eat in Madrid so it was a nice change.

Food was placed in front of us and that was that, no 'can i get you anything else' no offer of pepper or parmesan or any other drinks etc. I'm not one for being pestered whilst I eat but there is a happy medium somewhere. The waiters would disappear down the street and have a chat or be on their mobile. Like I said borderline hilarious. But if you fancy some italian food and don't care about the service then you should check it out.

review_preview: My husband and I were anxious to find an excellent restaurant that wasn't too expensive and not too far from our hotel (near the Prado Museum). Trip Advisor again came to the rescue. After reading the reviews, we decided to walk there quickly, in the...
review_full: My husband and I were anxious to find an excellent restaurant that wasn't too expensive and not too far from our hotel (near the Prado Museum). Trip Advisor again came to the rescue. After reading the reviews, we decided to walk there quickly, in the event that we would have to wait for a table. Thankfully, we were still on US dinner time (arrived around 8 pm) so we were one of the first to be seated (of course, it was packed by the time we were done). The restaurant is extremely small and we sat in the corner at a small table (with an admittedly uncomfortable chair). But the food was phenomenal -- the tastes were unique, creative and delicious. We had the marinated chicken with corn souffl√© -- superb; the chicken couscous was excellent; my husband talked about the sauce on the seafood pasta for days. We were a bit surprised that they did not serve any soft drinks (only wine) so we drank water. Not a problem -- we were there for the food anyway.

review_full: We both had pasta which was amazing and a tiramisu to follow which was also really good. Absolutely no complaints about the food at all. The service was a bit slapdash - we arrived and were sent downstairs to the colleague. Said colleague waved in the general direction of where she wanted us to sit. Things continued like that throughout our stay, almost as if it was an inconvenience to have us there. We ordered focaccia which never came but it did make an appearance on the bill. review_preview: We were staying on this street and walked by it several times and the pizza looked good.  So we decided to try it and we were not disappointed.  We started with the Spinaci, caprino, pomodori secchi, uvetta e pinoli salad that was easily split 4...
review_full: We were staying on this street and walked by it several times and the pizza looked good. So we decided to try it and we were not disappointed. We started with the Spinaci, caprino, pomodori secchi, uvetta e pinoli salad that was easily split 4 ways. We split 2 pizzas between 4 people. We ordered the margarita pizza with mushrooms added and the Luigi which had ham, spicy salami and mushrooms. Both pizzas were very tasty with plenty of toppings but not overwhelmingly so. The crust was very thin and the edges had the right amount of crunch. Add a bottle of wine and dinner was complete. Very reasonably priced for the amount and quality of food received. I definitely recommend this restaurant for the pizza and salad. We did not try the homemade pasta, but it looked wonderful as well. The service here was some of the best we encountered in Spain. Not only was our server friendly and helpful but the only server in almost 2 weeks that came back to check to see if everything was satisfactory.

So, take your chances!

We were happily surprised with the variety and freshness of the tapas selection and the little appetizers (including cheese, bread, and olives that were gratis/complementary with our meal). We ordered a caprese salad, hummus with pita, and a cheesy pork toast. It was plenty for two and very tasty! Super yummy and a good value!

title_review: Excellent tapas in a fun, friendly little place!
review_preview: For our last evening in Spain, we again consulted TripAdvisor and found another very highly rated, small tapas and wine bar that absolutely delivered on quality, friendliness, and comfort. On the ground floor is a tapas/wine bar with about 6 stools at the bar and...
review_full: For our last evening in Spain, we again consulted TripAdvisor and found another very highly rated, small tapas and wine bar that absolutely delivered on quality, friendliness, and comfort. On the ground floor is a tapas/wine bar with about 6 stools at the bar and downstairs about 6 tables with seating for around 20. Excellent tapas choices, beautiful presentation, and paced nicely for a lovely, unhurried dinner. Among the things we tried, the squid prepared in their own ink, duck "jam√≥n" with orange segments on toast, and the albondigas (meatballs) in tomato sauce were standouts, imo. Not far from Plaza Mayor, you may still need a bit of help from a GPS/map app to get there, but it's well worth the short walk.

review_preview: Our family of five ended up eating at Trattoria Malatesta two of the three nights we were in Madrid.  We all loved everything we tried which included the baked provolone, Margherita pizza, pasta bolognese, chicken saltimbocca, and pasta carbonara ( really amazing!!).  The second night...
review_full: Our family of five ended up eating at Trattoria Malatesta two of the three nights we were in Madrid. We all loved everything we tried which included the baked provolone, Margherita pizza, pasta bolognese, chicken saltimbocca, and pasta carbonara ( really amazing!!). The second night we even went for a second course dinner after paella elsewhere because we loved it so much the night before!! The prices are reasonable and the house red wine can't be beat. Try the meloncello after dinner...we'd never had it and were pleasantly surprised! It's an easy walk from Puerto del Sol where we stayed. And, best of all, we so loved our waiter Adrian. So very helpful and sweet! Highly recommend!

review_preview: We stopped in for a late lunch our last day in Madrid, and will absolutely return next time we visit. The service was incredibly fast, friendly, and the server was so helpful with all the questions we had. He recommended a few dishes because we...
review_full: We stopped in for a late lunch our last day in Madrid, and will absolutely return next time we visit. The service was incredibly fast, friendly, and the server was so helpful with all the questions we had. He recommended a few dishes because we weren't sure what to order, and they were heavenly! The beef in red spicy curry was our FAVORITE and probably one of the most delicious meals I ate in Spain. Very tender, flavorful, and not spicy (which was perfect for me... I didn't want picante). The pea/carrot mix they brought as an appetizer with bread was also fantastic and very flavorful!! It looked bland and plain, but tasted incredible. I DEFINITELY recommend giving this place a try!!! My husband had an excellent glass of red wine, as well, that the server chose.

review_preview: My wife and I visited here this week and initially we passed this place as it is only a small place and it was really busy We went back when it was quieter and we are so glad we did. My wife had been to...
review_full: My wife and I visited here this week and initially we passed this place as it is only a small place and it was really busy We went back when it was quieter and we are so glad we did. My wife had been to another place the rosa Negra which supposedly catered for coeliacs such as herself and she had had a bad reaction to the food but this place more than made up for the previous experience. The place itself is basic but the staff and the food were excellent. The guy serving us was so nice and helpful and we ordered five gluten free tapas which came with fresh bread and flat bread to go with the hummus. The chef there definitely has an excellent knowledge of ingredients and being inventive with his dishes. The food was top drawer and the wine was excellent. This is already at the top of our list for visiting again when we return to Madrid.

review_preview: The best Italian in memory in either the US or Spain. Delightful, interesting location on one of those ubiquitous tiny streets in the heart of Old Madrid. We had a cheese pizza, tagliatelle pasta with bolognese sauce and dessert of tiramisu and Panna cotta alla...
review_full: The best Italian in memory in either the US or Spain. Delightful, interesting location on one of those ubiquitous tiny streets in the heart of Old Madrid. We had a cheese pizza, tagliatelle pasta with bolognese sauce and dessert of tiramisu and Panna cotta alla vaniglia con frutti di bosco all washed down with sangria and a complementary cordial that I cannot identify. A little confusion on the ordering - pasta came first then pizza - something lost in translation more due to my poor Spanish. We ate early - right as they opened at 8:30 - as we were heading home the next morning. A line had already formed so reservations might be a good idea. If only someone could pick this place up and set it down in my neighborhood, I would eat there every night.

review_preview: Excellent food, reasonably priced, and a reasonable if not extensive wine list with some good Italian wines at sensible prices (I can recommend the Chianti Colli at ‚Ç¨20 a bottle).... and until what follows next, the staff had been helpful and attentive.However, our evening...
review_full: Excellent food, reasonably priced, and a reasonable if not extensive wine list with some good Italian wines at sensible prices (I can recommend the Chianti Colli at ‚Ç¨20 a bottle).... and until what follows next, the staff had been helpful and attentive. However, our evening was ruined when, prior to having dessert, we were told that we had to vacate our table in five minutes. We (a party of four) had arrived at 9.30pm and this was at 10.55pm. Apparently, they had another reservation booked for 11.00pm. The booking had been made via the internet and there was no indication that we only had the table for 1 1/2 hours, nor were we advised of this when we arrived. Into the bargain, restrictions on the amount of time you have a table are quite common in New York and, to a certain extent, in London but it's unheard of in Madrid... or at least among our party of ex-patriots each of whom had lived in the city around 20 years! (This is one of the reasons why I like living in Spain.) What was additionally annoying was that although the restaurant was busy (it was the last Friday before Christmas) there were still a couple of table free and some sensible floor management would have meant that those people who had booked a table could be accommodated without the inconvenience to my party. If you only want one (or two) courses and a quick meal then perhaps this is a place to go;  if you want a long convivial evening with a medium-sized group, then avoid! Into the bargain, when checking the bill, a couple of (admittedly small) extra items ended u on it that were not ordered. On principal, after the brusque way we were treated, I will not be returning here. For food I would rate this restaurant as a 5, for the way we were treated at the end, service gets a 1.

title_review: Great place to try out some unusual tapas!
review_preview: We came here on a Sunday night, and were lucky enough to get a table as we had our 2 year-old with us. The waiters were very friendly, and they have a menu in English. We tried all three of their hot tapas which were...
review_full: We came here on a Sunday night, and were lucky enough to get a table as we had our 2 year-old with us. The waiters were very friendly, and they have a menu in English. review_preview: We stayed in Madrid recently for four days so perhaps it was a bit naughty to stray from the local cuisine i.e. tapas et al and opt for something Italian. Well, we certainly didn't regret it. Nor did we feel guilty! We enjoyed our meal...
review_full: We stayed in Madrid recently for four days so perhaps it was a bit naughty to stray from the local cuisine i.e. tapas et al and opt for something Italian. Well, we certainly didn't regret it. Nor did we feel guilty! We enjoyed our meal here so much we had to go back a second time to make sure it wasn't a fluke the first time. The pizza was as authentic as one could hope for. (Not just in the way it was made/cooked but perhaps because the ingredients were also first class). Same could be said for the pasta dishes.The White Truffle pasta was heady and incredibly aromatic. And the Pasta alla Norma was a bit of a revelation. (We were so bowled over we actually tried to replicate this when we got back to London). The wine list was also excellent bearing in mind that this is a trattoria and by no means 'top-end' posh place. Hence the prices were very reasonable indeed including wines (which were close to normal, affordable retail prices unlike those in London which are generally marked up by a whopping 250%!) Service was very good and super prompt. Food arrived in good time and piping hot. The noise level wasn't too high either which meant even when it was rather busy one could still have a conversation without having to raise one's voice. Booking ahead is certainly advisable as this is understandably a popular place! I wish there were more places like this in London (which is usually a rip-off when it comes to dining at this level ). Two memorable evenings, thank you very much Malatesta.

The menu is available Spanish and English, including one "regular" and one with same dishes available entirely gluten free. We ordered several dishes off of both the regular and GF and they were both well plated, delicious selections. They also had a GF beer that was yummy. The GF bread was so much better than any we had tasted throughout Europe or the States The lovely woman waiting our table really added to the experience well beyond her dozens of trips hustling up and down those stairs, was her positive energy, constant smile on her face, in depth knowledge of menu. The wine and location added to the positive experience.

title_review: Finally, amazing simple food in Madrid
review_preview: Fantastic place with very simply freshly prepared tapas that we thoroughly enjoyed accompanied by excellent cava and Rioja at very cheap prices. After having been disappointed with all the food offerings in Madrid, we stopped by here tonight to see if our last meal in...
review_full: Fantastic place with very simply freshly prepared tapas that we thoroughly enjoyed accompanied by excellent cava and Rioja at very cheap prices. After having been disappointed with all the food offerings in Madrid, we stopped by here tonight to see if our last meal in Madrid and also our last meal for our 5 month European holiday was going to be memorable or uneventful. Well it will be memorable. We only shared 3 plates but the extras that came with the wine and the best hummus we've ever had make the whole experience brilliant. Thank you La Concha for ending our journey with a wonderful meal and environment. Final note, lovely friendly staff that don't treat you like a tourist! Outstanding.

It has a small bar area upstairs and a small seated area downstairs, but the staff are very friendly and pleasant. The big pull for me was the separate gluten free menu - we chose the gluten free prawns on toast, the meatballs and slow cooked pork, which came with gluten free bread, all of which were delicious! We arrived early (for Spain - 9.30pm) but very soon every table was full. Highly recommended

title_review: One of the best restaurants anywhere
review_preview: This restaurant is special from the moment you walk in the door. We were treated like family our first visit. The owners bring vegetables from family farms in Navarro each day and prepare them with such subtlety that they burst with the natural flavors. The...

The owners bring vegetables from family farms in Navarro each day and prepare them with such subtlety that they burst with the natural flavors. The fish was the best we have eaten anywhere - done to perfection with just the right amount of spice and olive oil. And the meat was the most tender and flavorful. The owners and the staff are warm and friendly, patient with limited Spanish and they went out of their way to make it a special evening for us. We have organized our trip to return before leaving Spain. If you are anywhere near Madrid, do not miss this restaurant!

title_review: One of the best in Madrid.
review_preview: If you search for first quality products and a respectful cuisine, this is the place to go. They make recipes from Navarra (Northern Spain) where quality is always the main goal. Excellent vegetables cooked to the precise point, that they receive from their home village...
review_full: If you search for first quality products and a respectful cuisine, this is the place to go. They make recipes from Navarra (Northern Spain) where quality is always the main goal. Excellent vegetables cooked to the precise point, that they receive from their home village daily, fine meats and the best fresh fish of every season. Service can¬¥t be better, kind, helpful and friendly. Nice and minimalistic venue that will make you feel comfortable. Many famous people are among their customers : former King of Spain, forme vice-president of the USA, politicians, sport stars, etc. But they give every customer the same loving care. My favourite place to go with family and friends and absolutely recommendable for everyone. You may try the artichokes, the "cardo" and the house "menestra". Don¬¥t forget to order the delicious "pimientos del cristal" (glass red peppers), hard to find in other places. No doubt, this is a "must" in Madrid.

While the meal was excellent (although the artichoke starter seemed under seasoned and perhaps overlooked) the high point was the dessert that the owner's wife suggested - Torrija caramelizada - a type of "French toast" but that name doesn't do it justice. We were the only Americans there and were treated like old friends by the time we left.

The food was a mix of traditional Spanish cuisine, the staff are all extremely friendly and the service was excellent. Casa Lucas was by no means the best food we had on our visit to Spain, but it was an exceedingly pleasant dinner and a great place for a relaxed Sunday dinner.

review_preview: As always, before writing a review, I read others to see if maybe there is something that hasn't been addressed or just to see if another "ditto" review even makes sense.I have spent several weeks in Madrid over the past year, specifically on or...
review_full: As always, before writing a review, I read others to see if maybe there is something that hasn't been addressed or just to see if another "ditto" review even makes sense. I have spent several weeks in Madrid over the past year, specifically on or very near Cava Baja and the appeal of Case Lucas escapes me, especially with SO many other options nearby. I've been there three times now, thinking perhaps I was missing something, as there is so much love for this place among TripAdvisor reviewers. I had the same reaction on this past visit. It's okay. Nothing more. The servers are very pleasant but the room is totally without charm. The food is nice though not fantastic nor worth the higher cost, compared to other local places. Poor (again, compared to other places on the street and elsewhere in Madrid) freebies when ordering drinks. Decent selection of wines but, again, nothing unique or even out of the ordinary. So, I don't see the need to try again. Of course, for those of my fellow travelers who love it, wonderful. Glad you enjoy it. For me, I will go elsewhere, enjoy the room and other patrons, and eat as well or better for less.

title_review: Favorite Madrid Restaurant! Seasonal, Simple, Delicous
review_preview: Every trip to Madrid for us includes a dinner at La Manduca.  The two owners run a tight ship and the food is incredible.  The have a fixed menu with diverse and mouthwatering appetizers, and the fish and meat main courses never disappoint.  Every night,...
review_full: Every trip to Madrid for us includes a dinner at La Manduca. The two owners run a tight ship and the food is incredible. The have a fixed menu with diverse and mouthwatering appetizers, and the fish and meat main courses never disappoint. Every night, depending on season and harvest, they have specials that are usually the stars of the night. Culinarily based in Navarra, the best dishes are always the vegetables: slowly cooked leeks, wonderfully soft and rich artichokes, savory and salty grilled mushrooms. Of the desserts, the Torrija is always an excellent choice. On top of all the amazing food, the modern yet warm interior architecture provides an elegant and special atmosphere for couples as well as groups. Absolutely recommendable.

review_full: This was lunch for 9 of us to celebrate a friend's landmark wedding anniversary.  A very minimalist restaurant in terms of decor, nothing to obstruct attention so one can enjoy wonderful simple preparaton of their food. The husband and wife owners were kind and gracious and made some good suggestions as to what to try. The veggie offerings were superb and enjoyed the peppers prepared very simply with no embellishments. Just the natural taste and goodness of fresh veggies to be savored.  Everybody enjoyed their entrees and had only good comments. I had the cochinillo confitado and it was excellently prepared. Others in my table had the sea bass, the lamb brain, and the rabo de toro. Desserts were just as good. We ordered three desserts and was shared by everybody for tastings.  Highly recommend to travelers to MAdrid. A little pricey but comparable to 5 star dining at major cities such as NYC, San Francisco or Napa.

review_preview: We met a friend here for our last lunch in Madrid. Man ducal is located in an upscale neighborhood, and it opens for lunch at 1:30. It is worth a visit, as it is definitely not a tourist stop, and all the tables were full....
review_full: We met a friend here for our last lunch in Madrid. Man ducal is located in an upscale neighborhood, and it opens for lunch at 1:30. It is worth a visit, as it is definitely not a tourist stop, and all the tables were full.  Our daughter's friend came with her newborn baby, and the wait staff was very gracious about accommodating her. The staff is very attentive. We tried a couple of tapas to share at the start, and we liked them all. One was a veggie dish. Two of us had fish dishes as our main courses; salmon and sea bass. I had the sea bass, and it was my least favorite dish. It was poached I believe, and was not cooked in the garlic, olive oil, and other spices I had hoped for. I would try something else next time, although the fish itself was good. Just a bit bland.  They also have nice wines by the glass. Expect to spend a couple of hours dining.

title_review: Sunday lunch with friends - and almost perfect!
review_preview: We 4, 2 from US and 2 Europeans, decided to have a big Sunday lunch here.  The waitress was nervous, but we did speak a bit of Spanish, so she relaxed and we all had a lovely, lovely meal.  One reason was the table next...
review_full: We 4, 2 from US and 2 Europeans, decided to have a big Sunday lunch here. The waitress was nervous, but we did speak a bit of Spanish, so she relaxed and we all had a lovely, lovely meal. One reason was the table next to us had 3 children, usually the kiss of death for a quiet, slow meal. But, all of the children were very well-behaved, with only one little incident, near the end of our meal. Thank you, thank you, thank you.  The restaurant is beautiful, with white tablecloths and napkins, all tables elegantly arrayed. It was truly a Sunday European long lunch, with excellent service and quiet attentiveness from the staff.   We ordered artichokes, anchovies, grilled bell peppers, sauteed leeks (amazingly cooked-they just melted in your mouth). Fresh monkfish, red tuna grilled, and oxtail with mushrooms.  Just listing the food does not do it justice. Each plate was cooked just right. Service paced our eating, the wine was superb - and thus, the day proceeded at a leisurely pace, with good friends and good food and good wine.  This is truly an exceptionally good restaurant, with standards maintained proudly. By the time we left, all of the staff lined up to shake our hands and wish us well. Madrid: you put on a show, and we are very lucky - and very grateful. To those of you considering eating here, the answer is yes, for a lengthy dining experience. We loved it.

review_preview: I have been returning to the region of Navarra for the last 40+ years and love the food in the region. When I was looking for a special restaurant for a friend who was celebrating her birthday in Madrid, I came across this restaurant. It...
review_full: I have been returning to the region of Navarra for the last 40+ years and love the food in the region. When I was looking for a special restaurant for a friend who was celebrating her birthday in Madrid, I came across this restaurant. It was a delight.  It is difficult to find restaurants anywhere that provide vegetables the respect that they deserve. And, La Manduca de Azagra is a prize restaurants for anyone looking for the perfect vegetable experience. Michelin guide also agrees. Plus, the vegetables are from one of the best food and wine regions of Spain, Navarra. Our menu consisted of fresh asparagas, crystal red peppers, artichokes (fried and boiled), and pochas (white beans that have been picked just before they fully mature). The wine selection is exceptional (affordable). I am a bargain wine person and know many of these wines. Imagine buying wth a meal Inurietta Crianza (Euros 17) or Sierra Cantabria Crianza (Euros 18)... amazing.

title_review: The ABSOLUTE BEST and freshest food!
review_preview: We ate at La Manduca for the first time in August.  We loved it so much, that we had to bring our daughter on a recent visit to Madrid.  Not only is the quality of the food superbly fresh and well prepared, but the owner/hostess...
review_full: We ate at La Manduca for the first time in August. We loved it so much, that we had to bring our daughter on a recent visit to Madrid. Not only is the quality of the food superbly fresh and well prepared, but the owner/hostess is the warmest and most caring person. She comes to your table and tells you which vegetables are the freshest for the night and highlights recommended menu items. A delicious tomato salad and yummy little sausages were brought as an amuse bouche. The gazpacho made with tomato, grapes and berries was SUBLIME, both in texture and flavor. White asparagus, prepared simply to let the asparagus shine, melted in your mouth. Sauteed artichokes and white beans were also delicious. Three of us shared the sirloin steak which was also perfectly prepared and DELICOUS. (Just a note, medium in Spain is what we in the US call medium/rare) Chocolate souffle was good, but the real star was the torija...like the lightest french toast filled with a creme bulee and carmelized sugar coating...outrageously good! To finish off the meal, a shot of an aperitif is on the house. Service was lovely and attentive. When we left, the owner wasn't around, but as we walked down the block, she caught us. She had run out of the restaurant to give us a hug and wish us well for the rest of our trip...how many proprietors do that? Delicious food, wonderful people. La Manduca is a MUST when in Madrid!!!! We will certainly be back when we have the opportunity!

title_review: First class simple dishes, excellent produce and a friendly attentive welcome and service.
review_preview: La Manduca di Azagra reminds me so much of my favourite restaurant, the River Cafe in London. Although obviously the focus here is not Italy but rather the simple authentic regional food of the Navarra in Spain. Great attention is paid to the high quality...
review_full: La Manduca di Azagra reminds me so much of my favourite restaurant, the River Cafe in London. Although obviously the focus here is not Italy but rather the simple authentic regional food of the Navarra in Spain. Great attention is paid to the high quality of the produce and its preparation. The owners take great care and pride to welcome you personally and explain the menu in detail. They and their staff are attentive throughout whilst at the same time not intruding. I think they achieve that balance because their enthusiasm is genuine and not forced. This was my second visit and a must for all future trips to Madrid. A memorable experience.

review_preview: My husband and I had been recommended this restaurant. I liked the menu for its traditional Navarra recipes, although I do not eat much meat and was concerned that it might be difficult to choose something I thought I would enjoy. The owners are clearly...
review_full: My husband and I had been recommended this restaurant. I liked the menu for its traditional Navarra recipes, although I do not eat much meat and was concerned that it might be difficult to choose something I thought I would enjoy. The owners are clearly very involved with the customers. Annabelle, who speaks very good English, explained many of the dishes to us and recommended that we have half portions of some of the dishes so we could try more flavours and also wine to accompany the meal. The vegetable dishes we tried - artichoke, thistle, red peppers and borage were delicious. We both chose fish as our main course. My tuna was cooked exactly as I asked and seasoned perfectly. My husband chose cod in tomatoes and rated it 8/10. The restaurant is unpretentious and the owners are clearly very proud of the food and wine they offer. I would wholeheartedly recommend it.
